docs.lead_paragraph: A few months after Virginia McGuire was found to have ovarian cancer a second time, she and her husband received a big tax refund. But did it make sense to put it toward retirement?

headline.seo: When Saving for Retirement Collides With a Lethal Illness
headline.main: Saving for Retirement as an Act of Wild Optimism
headline.print_headline: Saving for Retirement as an Act of Wild Optimism

docs.abstract: Virginia C McGuire essay describes her decision to continue saving for retirement despite uncertainties raised by recurrence of ovarian cancer.
docs.snippet: A few months after Virginia McGuire was found to have ovarian cancer a second time, she and her husband received a big tax refund. But did it make sense to put it toward retirement?

docs.lead_paragraph: Long-term care insurance is becoming increasingly complex and expensive, and it can be difficult to separate emotions from the financial considerations.

headline.seo: Expense and Emotions Affect Decisions About Long-Term Care
headline.main: Expense and Emotions in Preparing for Long-Term Care
headline.print_headline: Expense and Emotions in Preparing for Long-Term Care

docs.abstract: Long-term care insurance, which can provide live-in health care and other provisions for elderly, is becoming increasingly complex and expensive; decision to purchase such care can be confusing due to emotional considerations.
docs.snippet: Long-term care insurance is becoming increasingly complex and expensive, and it can be difficult to separate emotions from the financial considerations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Merton Simpson’s fortune is locked up in his art and the intrigue that has arisen since his death.

headline.seo: Merton Simpson Possessed Valuable Art but No Burial Money
headline.main: Art Worth Millions, Yet No Cash for Burial
headline.print_headline: Art Worth Millions, Yet No Cash for Burial

docs.abstract: Body of New York-based artist Merton D Simpson remains in funeral home two weeks after his death; family lacks funds for burial, despite fact that Simpson's prodigious art collection is worth millions of dollars, because his holdings are in dispute.
docs.snippet: Merton Simpson’s fortune is locked up in his art and the intrigue that has arisen since his death.

byline.original: By PATRICIA COHEN and PETER LATTMAN

docs.lead_paragraph: A survey found that employers are using both rewards and penalties in an effort to lower their health costs.

headline.seo: Employers Adding Incentives to Health Programs
headline.main: Companies Get Strict on Health of Workers
headline.print_headline: Companies Get Strict On Health Of Workers

docs.abstract: Survey of 800 large and midsize employers finds they are increasingly trying to lower health care costs by using incentives to persuade workers to make better lifestyle choices; what remains less clear is whether reward is better than punishment, or whether programs work at all.
docs.snippet: A survey found that employers are using both rewards and penalties in an effort to lower their health costs.

docs.lead_paragraph:
The government recommended years ago that all adolescent girls get a vaccine to protect against cervical cancer . But nearly seven years after it first came to market, an overwhelming majority of girls have yet to be inoculated.
 
Just 35 percent of girls 13 to 17 have received a full course of the vaccine, which inoculates against the strains of human papillomavirus that can cause cervical cancer, according to 2011 data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. And a study in Pediatrics this month , also based on C.D.C. data, says the intent to vaccinate is declining: 44 percent of parents in 2010 said they did not intend to vaccinate, up from 40 percent in 2008.
docs.snippet:
The government recommended years ago that all adolescent girls get a vaccine to protect against  cervical cancer . But nearly seven years after it first came to market, an overwhelming majority of girls have yet to be inoculated.
   
Just 35...

docs.abstract: Health professionals hope to make the shots more accessible, and to make the vaccine sound less scary to parents and daughters.
docs.snippet: Health professionals hope to make the shots more accessible, and to make the vaccine sound less scary to parents and daughters.

docs.lead_paragraph: The state opens a health care hot line for a few hours each year for patients who do not qualify for Medicaid. Thousands try, but not many qualify for the limited funds.

headline.seo: In Tennessee, a Telephone Race for Medicaid
headline.main: Tennessee Race for Medicaid: Dial Fast and Try, Try Again
headline.print_headline: Tennessee Race for Medicaid: Dial Fast and Try, Try Again

docs.abstract: Tennessee opens a health care hot line two nights a year for residents who have high medical bills but do not normally qualify for Medicaid; line shuts down after 2,500 calls, typically within an hour; thousands try, but not many qualify for the limited funds, as applicants must be elderly, blind, disabled or a caretaker for a child who qualifies.
docs.snippet: The state opens a health care hot line for a few hours each year for patients who do not qualify for Medicaid. Thousands try, but not many qualify for the limited funds.
